NEWS
LETTER
OCT. 1, T 953
A Chance to Work for
Better Radio TV
In Minneapolis, on June 24, 1953, the
American Council for Better Broadcasts
was formed. Representatives from 18 na¬
tional organizations, 18 state groups, and
many local organizations attended the or¬
ganizational meetings. Delegates were there
from 93 cities in 34 states.
They formed the AMERICAN COUN¬
CIL FOR BETTER BROADCASTS, a non¬
profit, coordinating organization, to corre¬
late the efforts of scattered groups and indi¬
viduals for better radio-TV programming.
The PURPOSE is to stimulate the broad¬
casting of good radio and television pro¬
grams; to study, in order to arrive at stand¬
ards for judging programs; and to encourage
all radio and television stations in fulfilling
their obligations to ‘‘serve the public in¬
terest, convenience and necessity.”
For nation-wide impact, the Council
agrees to unite on one nation-wide project,
each year. The 1953-54 project is the
LOOK LISTEN PROJECT. It asks groups
to enlist as many members as possible (and
others) to rate 8 network programs (3-10
P.M.) on one radio or television station,
and tell why they rated the programs as
they did. The reports need to be in by Jan¬
uary 31, if they are to be included in the
1954 report that goes to sponsors, broad¬
casters, and the Federal Communications
Commission.
WRITE TO MRS. G. F. MATTHEWS,
4539 Winnequah Road, Madison, Wiscon¬
sin for instructions and sample materials.
Project materials are free, except the 8
report cards for each monitor (3c per per¬
son). These cards may be copied locally
if the identical form and size are used.
MEMBERSHIP is open to individuals
who are not professional broadcasters; and
to national, state, and local organizations
(except broadcasters’ groups and listeners’
groups having broadcasters as members)
who will undertake together annually one
constructive project, to be agreed upon at
the annual meeting. Their other activities
in the field of radio and television are of
their own choice. High schools and col¬
leges and separate classes in them are elig¬
ible to membership.
THE INSIGNIA AND SLOGANS
above are borrowed from the Wis¬
consin Association for Better Radio
and Television, Do you like them?
Shall we adopt them, if we get its
permission? Or would you like some¬
thing else? We’d like to hear from
you.

Children’s Television
Children have strong tastes for programs
adults consider not good for them. The
British Broadcasting Company believes this
demand should be partially met. But, ac¬
cording to the Educational Supplement of
the London Times, it keeps in mind the
‘‘solitary viewer’s vulnerability to fear. Bad
men are allowed to be really bad, and the
child has the satisfaction of seeing the good
ones treat them as they deserve. Neverthe¬
less it is careful not to restrict its work to
any over-tight theories about audience’s
preferences. It tries to give abundant
diversity.”
A few of its entertainment programs have
secondary educational benefits. “Through
plays it may try to awaken curiosity about
painting or history; other programmes—a
story begun and left in the air, or imaginary
conversation with dead authors—are planned
as an incitement to reading; others coax the
audience to watch birds or to use their
hands.”
People Seem Pleased
People have expressed gratification.
Mrs. Gertrude Broderick, President of the
Association for Education by Radio-TV,
says: “You are to be congratulated on the
fine progress you have made in such a
short time, and I have every confidence that
this newest effort will bear fruit a thousand¬
fold.”
William D. Boutwell, Editor of Scholastic
Teacher, “I am very pleased to know you
are making such progress with the Council
for Better Broadcasts.”
Norman Cousins, Editor, Saturday Re¬
view of Literature, “I am delighted to learn
of your new Coordinating Council. It is
tremendously heartening to see the increased
effectiveness of your work and to observe
the actual evidence of your growth.”
Franklin Dunham, Chief of Radio-TV,
U. S. Office of Education, “More Power to
you.”
Arthur J. Freund, Chairman of Section
on Criminal Law, American Bar Ass’n,
“You are engaged in a most worthy and
highly necessary endeavor. I want to as¬
sure you of my deep personal interest and
concern.”
Charles A. Siepmann, Chairman, Commu¬
nications Dep’t, New York University, “I’m
delighted that your organization goes so
well.”
Ralph Steetle, Executive Director, Joint
Committee on Educational Television, “It
seems to me that the American Council has
a challenging assignment before it.”
NOTES ON MAGAZINES
The first issue this fall of Parent-Teacher
Magazine carries an account of the forming
of the Council for Better Broadcasts in the
column, "What’s Happening in Education.”
The Journal of the Association for Edu-
cation-TV tells the story of the Council’s
organizational meetings and its objectives.
Response to "Variety"
In response to its article about the ACBB
organizational meetings in Minneapolis,
Variety received a letter from Shigeru Nak¬
amura, Director of the Radio Culture Re¬
search Institute of Japan. He said, in part.
“We are anxious to know how the Council
is organized, i.e. the names of its members,
and how they intend to raise radio and TV
programming standards.”
